item.title: From 4 Minutes to 3 Seconds: How Database Transaction Rollback Revolutionized Test Suite
item.author: Michael Nikitochkin
item.content:encoded:
In a single afternoon, I transformed my test suite from a 4-minute ordeal into a 3-second sprint by replacing expensive database with lightning-fast . This 98.8% performance improvement didn't just make developers happierâ€”it fundamentally changed how I approach testing. 447 tests now run in instead of â€”a that makes test-driven development (TDD) practical again.
The Problem: When Tests Become a Bottleneck The test suite was destroying developer productivity. Every pull request meant waiting, every bug fix meant coffee breaks. With truncation-based test isolation, the team was hemorrhaging time:UserTest#test_email_validation -
The Root Cause: Truncation Hell The culprit was my test isolation strategy: . Before each test, I was:Dropping and recreating data across 20+ tablesPerforming expensive I/O operations that scaled with data sizeEach test was paying a tax just to clean up after itself. With 447 tests, that's over 3 minutes of pure overhead.
The Solution: Transaction Rollback Strategy Instead of physically deleting data and resetting sequences, I could simply wrap each test in a database transaction and . transactions are designed for exactly thisâ€”atomic operations that can be discarded instantly. - Database schema loading, migrations, etc.Only test data is transactional - All changes disappear instantly - is just a memory operation - Each test gets a fresh slate automatically
Performance Transformation
Dramatic Individual Test Speedup Example: User::ValidateTest#test_email_validation
What This Means for Developers Before (Truncation Hell):"I'll run tests while grabbing coffee" - waiting kills productivity1.8 tests per minute - glacial feedback4+ minute feedback loop - context switching inevitable - testing becomes optionalAfter (Transaction Magic):"I'll run tests before every commit" - instant gratification9,450 tests per minute - blazing speed3-second feedback loop - you're still thinking about the code - testing becomes second nature
The Problem: Expensive Database Surgery Each test paid ~40-60ms of truncation overhead: 20-30ms (disk I/O) 10-15ms (catalog updates) 5-10msWith 447 tests, that's over 3 minutes of pure cleanup time.
The Solution: Instant Rollback Transaction rollback costs ~2-4ms per test (50-75% reduction): 1-2ms (memory allocation) 1-2ms (memory discard) Pure memory operation![IMAGE PLACEHOLDER: Prompt: Performance cost breakdown comparison chart. Left bar showing truncation costs: "TRUNCATE ops (20-30ms)" in red, "Sequence resets (10-15ms)" in orange, "Connection overhead (5-10ms)" in yellow, totaling 40-60ms per test. Right bar showing rollback costs: "Transaction start (1-2ms)" in light blue, "Rollback (1-2ms)" in dark blue, totaling 2-4ms per test. Include annotations: "50-75% reduction" and "Pure memory operation" for rollback. Style: modern bar chart with gradient colors, clear cost labels, benchmark comparison.]Override 's method to wrap test execution in database transactions:Setup OUTSIDE transaction - Database schema and reference data loads once per test suite - Each test runs atomically and always rolls back - Clear caches (, converted models, email collectors, )Why Override Instead of Using Standard Hooks?The core issue is how 's works: uses to execute code inside a transaction blockIt sets thread-local variables to track the active transaction connectionIndividual database operations check these thread variables to reuse the transaction connectionThis pattern requires wrapping the from the outsideStandard lifecycle hooks have a fatal limitation, as there is no or wrapper mechanism.By overriding , we control the of operations and can properly use :1. Setup (OUTSIDE transaction) â† Reference data persists 2. Begin transaction with yield 3. Test code (INSIDE transaction) â† Thread variables track connection 4. Rollback transaction 5. Teardown (OUTSIDE transaction) â† Clear caches, email collectors

item.title: Crystal Minitest and the Shutdown Order Problem
item.author: Michael Nikitochkin
item.content:encoded:
: Optimizing setup by moving initialization from to module-level broke logging: creates resources early, and they're cleaned up before tests run (which happens in ). Solution: use for tests instead.
Story: The Optimization and Discovery When setting up a application to work with , I moved all initialization instructions to hooks:After tests were working reliably, I optimized: why run this repetitive setup for every test? If I moved it to module-level initialization, it would run once when test file loads:Tests passed initially. But when I ran with to enable verbose output, something broke:1 crystal run /users_test.cr Channel::ClosedError: Channel is closed /usr/share/crystal/src/channel.cr:142:8 in 'send' /usr/share/crystal/src/log/dispatch.cr:55:7 in 'dispatch' The logging channel was closed. I reverted to as a workaround, but I needed to understand: Why does setup runs matter more than it runs?
Investigation: The Key Discovery
Why Minitest Is Different doesn't run tests during normal program execution. Instead:This creates a timing problem. With module-level setup: initialize a Log instance with on booting spawns a background fiber with a channelMain program completes â†’ runtime cleanup beginsChannel may be closed by garbage collection (this is where my assumption lies) fires â†’ runs testsTests call â†’ channel already closed â†’ With , setup happens inside , so the instance is created during shutdown, not during normal execution.
How Works During shutdown, garbage collection calls , which closes the channel. But hooks run some cleanup, creating the race condition.The issue isn't optimization itselfâ€”it's that isn't suitable for code that runs before . The solution is to use a dispatcher without background resources for tests:For tests with module-level init, is ideal.The optimization itself was soundâ€”module-level initialization faster. The issue was incompatibility with in a shutdown context.More broadly, any code that relies on objects with finalize methods could be affected by garbage collection events and timingâ€”background resources created during normal execution may be cleaned up before tests run.The fix is simple (one configuration change) but reveals a broader principle:Test infrastructure must account for shutdown order and resource cleanup timing, regardless of framework. Some libraries use handlers for cleanup in multi-threaded applications, and when tests run after these handlers, any finalized objects (channels, connections, files, caches) become inaccessible.
